Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

Yes, and its easy to think "oh but look it shows I'm responsible and I care," no, it doesn't. It shows that only sometimes you think the class is important and that they have nothing else better to do but to answer your tiny email. You aren't their only student nor their only class, your professor is not your messenger boy.

Real lpt… when you miss class, check the syllabus for what lecture was scheduled that day. Skim the the book/ask a friend for the notes until you find something you genuinely don’t understand. Ask the professor about it during office hours or next class
I always respond to that question: Yes, you could ask to one of your peers for the class notes. I wouldn't say it feels insulting but you sure won't be making extra points for participation in class.

Former professor here. 

It’s not only insulting, it’s infuriating. By our standards, you HAVE and ALWAYS WILL HAVE missed important material if you aren’t in attendance. Most of us in the liberal arts have 15 weeks in which to deliver 20-25 chapters (as a general benchmark) of content. We spend weeks perfecting that syllabus every damn semester, only for it to be ignored despite the fact that it lays out the entire course, all the readings, and all the homework*. It’s beyond insulting, it’s like you could care less and thus it not only irritates the professor, it makes you look like a lazy fool and I guarantee it impacts your grade in some way, given how subjective they are. There have definitely been times when I’ve declined to round up an 87.5 to an A- for a student who had pestered me with b.s. like that (more than once). 

* Even if the syllabus is sparse or the class behind/ahead, there are *how many other students* in the class you could ask? 

If you *are* going to ask the prof because the syllabus is crap and fellow students have been unhelpful - at least try to ask during office hours, not just before/after the lecture. And if you communicate by email, make sure that email has a decent subject line, a professional greeting, polite language, and is free of spelling/grammar errors - it’s one thing to be a bit annoying, it’s another thing to be purposely obtuse.

* PS. if you aren’t getting a detailed syllabus from your professor with all the info you need (assuming the missing info isn’t online somewhere), complain to the department chair and then feel free to annoy the fuck out of them with your “did I miss anything?s”.
